### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

On a rather large subtree on an even larger disk, I'm encountering the following error:

````
PS❯  Get-ChildItem -File -Force -Recurse -LiteralPath 'J:\<REDACTED>.20211120\C\' | % { $_.FullName} | Out-File c:/tmp/allfiles_ps_fullnames.txt
Get-ChildItem: The system cannot find the file specified.
````

with both 7.2.1 and 7.3.0-preview.1.

Enumerating the same tree in `CMD` using `DIR /S /B /A-D J:\<REDACTED>.20211120\C` returns 519,834 files (and no error). The aforementioned incomplete PowerShell output has 152,415 entries.

The same pipeline also fails in Windows PowerShell 5.1:

````
PS❯  Get-ChildItem -File -Force -Recurse -LiteralPath 'J:\<REDACTED>.20211120\C\' | % { $_.FullName} | Out-File c:/tmp/allfiles_wps51_fullnames.txt
The script failed due to call depth overflow.
At line:1 char:1
+ Get-ChildItem -File -Force -Recurse -LiteralPath 'J:\<REDACTED>.20211120 ...
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : InvalidOperation: (0:Int32) [], RuntimeException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : CallDepthOverflow
````

`Get-Error` suggests something symlink/junction-related, but doesn't indicate the offending item(s).

Process Monitor didn't give me any clue (no "not found" error there).

### Expected behavior

```console
The entire tree should be enumerated.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Enumeration fails somewhere during the recursive scan.
```
